q1.text: What do you infer from the phrase "Climate Smart Agriculture"?

answers.text: "Climate Smart Agriculture" refers to the production systems that sustainably increase productivity, resilience (adaptation), reduce/remove Green House Gas GHG (mitigation), and enhance achievement of national food security and development goals. It is an approach that aims to transform agriculture in developing countries to respond to the challenges of achieving food security under the pressure posed by an increasing population and the threats posed by climate change.

q2.text: How is Vietnam being the centre of CSA?

answers.text: Vietnam is not the center of CSA. However, Vietnam is one of the countries that has partnered with FAO/EPIC for a project that builds the necessary technical, policy and financing basis for achieving CSA in the respective countries. The project aims to provide an evidence base for identifying, developing and implementing practices, policies and investments for climate smart agriculture and develop a country-owned strategic framework to guide action and investment on CSA. Additionally, a workshop was organized in Hanoi, Vietnam, in May 2014 to review investment proposals and develop policy recommendations using future scenarios to guide planning.

q3.text: Why do you think Vietnam has been chosen for CSA??

answers.text: Vietnam has been chosen for CSA because it is facing significant challenges in achieving food security due to an increasing population and the threats posed by climate change. Agriculture in developing countries must undergo significant transformation to respond to these challenges, and CSA is seen as a key role in this transformation. Additionally, Vietnam is losing agricultural land at a rate of 100,000 hectares per year, which further exacerbates the food security challenge. The FAO/EPIC project aims to build the necessary technical, policy, and financing basis for achieving CSA in Vietnam, among other countries.

The FAO's EPIC (Economics and Policy Innovations for Climate Smart Agriculture) programme is aimed at developing tools, knowledge, and partnerships to support countries in achieving climate-smart agriculture. It was initiated in 2010 by the agricultural development economics division (ESA) of the FAO. The programme has partnered with Zambia, Malawi, and Vietnam to build the necessary technical, policy, and financing basis for achieving CSA in the respective countries. Its objectives are to provide an evidence base for identifying, developing and implementing practices, policies, and investments for climate-smart agriculture and to develop a country-owned strategic framework to guide action and investment on CSA.

q5.text: Why is investment for CSA crucial?

answers.text: Investment for Climate-Smart Agriculture (CSA) is crucial because it promotes sustainable production systems that increase productivity, resilience, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and enhance national food security and development goals. CSA investment proposals are reviewed and revised to make them feasible under diverse scenarios. The investment in CSA is regarded as an entry point for essential information on how to make agriculture, forestry, and fisheries part of the solution to the negative impacts of climate change. The FAO Economics and Policy Innovations for Climate-Smart Agriculture (EPIC) Programme and the CGIAR Research Program on Climate Change, Agriculture, and Food Security (CCAFS) are working together to organize CSA investment proposals and policy recommendations for Viet Nam, based on future climate and socio-economic scenarios.

q6.text: How has EPIC collaborated with the CCAFS programme?

answers.text: The FAO Economics and Policy Innovations for Climate-Smart Agriculture (EPIC) Programme has collaborated with the CGIAR Research Program on Climate Change, Agriculture and Food Security (CCAFS) to organize Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA) investment proposals and policy recommendations for Viet Nam, based on future climate and socio-economic scenarios. The FAO/CCAFS scenarios process has focused on contextual drivers of change for Climate Smart Agriculture – climate change and socio-economic changes. The project has both research and policy activities, as well as collaboration with international research and policy institutions including CCAFS.

q7.text: How do the objectives of EPIC and CCAFS concur?

answers.text: The FAO Economics and Policy Innovations for Climate-Smart Agriculture (EPIC) Programme and the CGIAR Research Program on Climate Change, Agriculture and Food Security (CCAFS) are working together to organize Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA) investment proposals and policy recommendations for countries, based on future climate and socio-economic scenarios. Both EPIC and CCAFS aim to develop tools, knowledge, and partnerships to support countries in achieving climate-smart agriculture. They also collaborate with international research and policy institutions to address the challenges of global warming and declining food security on agricultural practices, policies, and measures. Therefore, the objectives of EPIC and CCAFS concur in promoting climate-smart agriculture and addressing the challenges of climate change and food security.

q8.text: Discuss the geographical and climatic behaviour of Southeast Asia.

answers.text: Southeast Asia has a land surface of 4,000,000 km2 and is home to 620 million people, projected to increase by at least 150 million by the 2050s. The region has huge disparities in Human Development Indices and governance styles. The dominant climate is hot and humid year-round with high rainfall. Southeast Asia’s annual wet and dry seasons are driven through seasonal wind shifts triggering monsoon rains. The tropical rain belt causes additional rainfall during the monsoon. Except for regions of high altitudes, northern Vietnam is the only major zone in Southeast Asia with a subtropical climate and cold winter. With long coasts, many Southeast Asian countries are among the most exposed to natural hazards, in particular typhoons, storm surges, and flooding.
